text:
It would be interesting to know what happened in the Arctic during the 10,800 BCE abrupt climate change. We know there were two ice sheets - smaller Cordilleran and bigger Laurentide on North America. The Laurentide perhaps 3 - 4 km thick at some places. 

There was a paper published in Feb 2018 in The Journal of Geology about extraordinary biomass burning around 10,800 BCE. It is fascinating.

Adjusted quote: "Around 10,800 BCE, likely within the span of 21 years between 10,818 BCE and 10,797 BCE, ‚àº9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ‚àº10 million km2 (area as big as the US), burned. The concentrations of soot, used to estimate the global amount of biomass burned, suggest that wildfires around 10,800 BCE consumed considerably more biomass than during the K-Pg extinction event."

If interested the links are https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/695703?journalCode=jg for part 1 and https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/695704 for part 2. 

It would be interesting to calculate how much CO2 must have been released when ‚àº9% of world terrestrial biomass on ‚àº10 million km2 burned. The wildfires on 70,000 km¬≤ in Australia this year are estimated to release about 900 million tons of CO2, which equals to double the country's total yearly fossil fuel emissions."

Perhaps CO2 released by burning of ‚àº9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ‚àº10 million km2 might have contributed to melting of Cordilleran and Laurentide ice sheets? At present CO2 melts ice in Arctic, Greenlad, Antarctica so we can assume it should have been melting ice also around 10,800 BCE as well. 

There is a puzzling energy paradox. Melting of ice sheets happened during very cold period, so it should not have happened.

What mechanisms or combination of might have caused rapid melting of several kilometres thick ice sheets?

One simple physics principle is that the weight of several millions cubic kilometres of ice pushes the continent down. Heavy ice depresses the surface, at times pushing it below sea level, making the ice sheets to get in contact with warmer ocean, causing the ice sheets to retreat and stabilizing the system. Destabilize the system enough with a powerful external factor and things start moving quickly. 

Recent scientific papers start to provide more and more evidence that an external fast acting factor was in effect around 10,800 BCE. 

The paper published in March 2020 in Nature provides evidence of cosmic impact at Syria, coeval with impacts that deposited high-temperature meltglass, melted microspherules, and/or platinum at >50 sites on four continents around 10,800 BCE. Link to the article https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w

Impact on several kilometres thick ice sheet in Canada would not have left a permanent crater imprinted in the ground but more likely a depression filled with water which today would be in the form of a lake. 

There are several candidates for comet fragments impacts on ice sheet in Canada around 10,800 BCE. One of them possibly in Great Lakes area, perhaps the Saginaw Bay, Michigan // Lake Nippon // Manicouagan Reservoir // Gulf of Saint Lawrence // 

It is suggested it started in direction from Western coast to Eastern coast. 

It would be interesting to check the known impact craters in the world for a possible "string impacts. Just a few candidates - Rochechouart crater in France, Saint Martin crater in Manitoba, Obolon crater in Ukraine, Red Wing crater in North Dakota. If there is any researcher or enthusiast out there able to get some funding go for it.:-)

If you have not seen a string impact video please check the well-known Shoemaker‚ÄìLevy 9 string impacts on Jupiter in July 1994 on BBC Studios YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DgOTcIfU75Y

As mentioned in the March 2020 paper in Nature (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w) there might have been multiple airbursts/impacts across at least four continents. These are proposed to have resulted from a one of a series of short-period, active comets known to break up frequently and to shed dozens to thousands of fragments that are 10 to 1000‚Äâm‚Äâin diameter, each capable of producing catastrophic airburst/impacts. The largest cometary debris clusters are proposed to be capable of causing thousands of airbursts within a span of minutes across one entire hemisphere of Earth. An encounter with such a million-km-wide debris cluster would be thousands of times more probable than a collision with a 100-km-wide comet or a 10-km asteroid.

text:
I have seldom seen such nonsense as presented in this BBC report.


I am Australia's leading climate scientist.
So much nonsense is seen on US and UK media about the bush fires here in Australia.

Bush fires are normal in Australia and have happened every summer for tens of thousands of years.
This time however, they are more widespread and intense than usual in some parts of the country. This is due to many local and state governments being influenced over the last 3 decades by policies of The Greens, which is to prevent fuel reduction burns. Historically these have been carried out for thousands of years in winter, to prevent the vast conflagrations we are seeing now.
Bush-fire Scientist David Packham predicted massive out-of-control fires will happen if Loony "Green ideology is not stopped".
He said forest fuel levels had climbed to their most dangerous level in thousands of years because of "misguided green ideology".

Wild Fires are inevitable in Australia. Uncontrollable conflagrations near residential areas are not.
Green activists who actively prevented the usual fuel reduction burns and sabotaged fire-fighting equipment must accept the responsibility for the extent of this summer's fires, along with the many arsonists. Most fires this season were started by humans.
The real question is; which US billionaire is paying these climate activists to sabotage fire-fighting equipment, and to start fires?
author: 1000frolly PhD

text: It would appear (from a non-political) viewpoint that the massive Hadley cell circulation is expanding, both the Hadley and North and South Polar cells are decreasing in size and strength and this will give rise to more (as Thummarukudy of UNEP put it) "More Hydro-meteorological events", I calculated that here in the United States (we) would experience some very nasty low-level convective events including but definitely not limited to monsoon-level rains and enormous Mesoscale Convective Complexes (MCCs) from the central plains to the eastern seaboard. I hope that I am wrong. Anyone who has experienced a hurricane (tropical cyclone, tropical storm, etc.) knows all too well the dangers after such storm systems have passed. Cholera, malaria, waterborne diseases and deadly viruses have been known to break out during sudden shifts in global climate.
author: Trevyr Corey

_"NSW has been the epicentre of Australia's bushfire crisis, but the facts show arson has little to do with it.

This week, a NSW Police media release revealed 24 people had been charged over deliberately-lit bushfires this season.

However, the majority of suspected arson relates to small grass fires and rubbish bins set alight, which have inflicted negligible damage and burnt a tiny area compared with fires sparked by lightning.

The Gospers Mountain "mega-blaze" and the Green Wattle Creek fire, which are both near Sydney, were ignited by lightning.

All the major blazes in the Snowy Mountains and South Coast which have taken hold since New Year's Eve were also started by lightning.

This includes the Dunns Road and Green Valley fires burning near the state's south border, which on Friday formed a new "mega-blaze"."_

There's only 1 natural predator to the 3 largest species of kangaroos, has been that way for 30,000 years & everything worked just fine until these grass eating hippies started saying "oh the poor kangaroos, they look cute, you can't eat them" & so the homosapians were lost as natural predator & kangaroos have been experiencing "boom & bust" periods with constant population bottlenecks ever since & these idiot vegans still refuse to just shoot & eat the excess to keep the population in check & instead insist on catching each of the 50 million roos to implant them with contraceptives, at a cost of over $1000 per roo - and HUGE trauma for it! text:
Please see Video Tutorial Cures Climate Hysteria at http://renewable.50webs.com/Video-Tutorial.html  The solar system wide climate discovery by Dr. Ned Nikolov and Dr. Karl Zeller is based on official NASA space probe data.  They used advanced mathematical analysis techniques to study the climates of rocky surfaced planets and moons in our solar system.  They found they could accurately predict their long term average surface temperatures by knowing just two strategic facts: their distance from the Sun and their atmospheric pressure.  This formula has worked correctly for Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, and Pluto, and for Earth‚Äôs moon, Europa, Callisto, Titan, and Triton.  Their predictions have been proven accurate to within one degree Celsius.  Like the value of Pi, this mathematical relationship will never go away because it was created by Nature, not by man.

     Nikolov and Zeller found that the specific gaseous composition of the atmospheres of planets and moons are irrelevant to determining their long-term average surface temperatures.  For example, the atmosphere of Venus is composed of 96.5% carbon dioxide, while Earth‚Äôs atmosphere contains only .04% carbon dioxide, yet that information was not even needed to predict temperature.  The logical conclusion is that atmospheric gases only contribute to warming by their physical mass, which increases atmospheric pressure.

text: Climate change is only small not as they are putting it all over the media. The earth is about four billion years old and has always gone through stages of cooling down and heating up. CO2 is the gas of life. We breath it out, plants and treas breath it in then release oxygen, without one and another trees etc would not exit and neither would we. The oceans cover most of the planet and release CO2 as well. The more the better, it does not warm the planet as much as we are being told. They called it global warming originally but had to change it to climate change when they realised the average temperatures were slightly going down. They lie to us and try and brain wash us through the media etc etc for reasons to suit them. Their aim is for global control and profit from introducing green tax on systems etc saying they will cool the planet, but it will be going in their pockets and other things, not cooling the planet. Problem, action solution. Create the man made climate change lie, when man has almost nothing to do with it, wait for the reaction, protests etc, which is exactly what they want, then hey presto, offer the solution. New tax regimes. If they didn‚Äôt create the lie, and just try and implement the new tax regimes, a lot of those climate protesters today would be out protesting against the new tax regimes. Fact. The scientists that agree with them are government funded through universities etc so their hands are tied and they can‚Äôt speak freely and have to go along with the governments. The scientists who are independent whose hands are not tied will tell you the same as me but in much more details. They try to shut them up in various ways and even ban them from publishing their own facts in some cases. People need to look the proper facts up and realise what‚Äôs going on. The main cause for global cooling or warming is down to decreased or increased solar activity on the surface of the sun. The solar rays from increased sun spot activity break through the earths atmosphere and warm the oceans slightly. Also the moon is affected which effects the tides, and it effects the jet steam moving it slightly  up or down, which‚Äôs effects the weather one way or another above it it and below it. I will say this though. I am all for the local environment issues. Car exhaust fumes etc which effect people with bronchitis etc and skin problems. The waste plastic in our oceans needs to be addressed too and other issues. Check out piers corbyn for climate facts. He is an independent scientist as well as many others. CO2 does not create warming, it follows it. Also when the temperature goes down it then follows that too, but there is an 8 hundred year lag before it starts to follow it due to the slower temperature changes in the oceans. Most of the planet is ocean and the warmer they are the more CO2 they emit. The charts originally showed that lag too with the spikes in temperature and CO2 being 8 hundred years apart but they falsified the charts and put both the spikes together to make it look like CO2 was to blame to suit their own agenda as explained above. If they were so worried about man made CO2 then why do they not do something about termites which create ten times more CO2 than we do ?. Out of the whole atmosphere only about 0.04 percent of it is CO2 and only about 4 percent of that 0.04 percent is man made. Also think about this one. Why are developers investing in building all around the world on coast lines if they think in about 20 years time they will be flooded? Also why are the banks investing money to those developers to help them build, and providing long term mortgages to people to buy those properties etc on the coast lines? The answer to that is they know damn well that man made climate change is a hoax. I will mention again, check out piers corbyn and others, independent scientists, not government funded, hands not tied and can speak freely without the risk of loosing their livelihood. Again think about this. Out of the whole of the earths atmosphere, only about 0.04 percent of it is CO2. From that, only 4 percent of that 0.04 percent is CO2 that is man made. ( That‚Äôs not even a fart in the wind ). Thank you for reading this.

text: ¬†@Rarosue Amaraibi.¬† I have watched, It's nice :-) Carbon capture tech. from air have no sense if we continue to release CO2 from every chimney EL. power plant or heating plant. FIRST we have to install scrubbers on every that chimney and store collected CO2 underground. Capturing on the source from chimney gases  that have 10% CO2  is much easier and more efficient than from air that have 0,04% CO2. You need energy to do so and at power plant is already available. Solar and wind is the future.

There is no much sense if you trash your garbage on the street and where ever you are and not in recycle bin and than someone will collect that garbage all around . CO2 emissions 60% are from electricity production and heating systems during winter and 25% is cars. We can solve those 60% with measure that will collect CO2 on source where is produced. Collecting 10% CO2 mixture of gases that comes from every chimney of some electricity production power plant is much easier and more efficient that collecting from air (do not trash garbage on the street).
Rest 25% emissions from cars should be moved to electric cars .
I'm too for capture from air but first things first. Please distinguish these two things capture on source and capture from air.

text: ¬†@Dink Winkingson¬†I came to this conclusion by watching/reading a few news sources and I've got a background in forest management. Forest fires aren't extinguished or prevented by climate change activism. People are being distracted and misled in my opinion and the result is likely to be history repeating itself. To be clear, I'm not denying climate change is a contributing factor but the priority should not be fighting an unwinnable battle against climate change. Specific policy regarding the initial cause of and prevention of damage on this scale needs to be put in place and discussed. Every natural disaster is blamed on climate change these days. It achieves nothing.

author: Keith Outside the box

text:
¬†@Kent Horvath¬† Australian here (living in Canberra). At least hundreds of people will have died due to the heatwaves (this hasn't been tallied yet but in 2009, 435 people died from heatstroke -- this year has been far hotter). The Sydney suburb of Penrith hit 48.9C, making it the hottest place on Earth at the time. The previous record was 47.8C, recorded in 1939. That's a huge difference. Canberra also smashed its all time record by over 2C, as did many other cities and measuring locations. For the elderly, or those who don't own air conditioners, or young children, that can be extremely dangerous.

So it's not all about the direct deaths due to the fires mate. It's about the indirect effects of the smoke pollution, which makes it impossible to go about daily life. It's about the effects on the agricultural and forestry sectors, which had hundreds of thousands of hectares of produce and timber plantations destroyed. It's about the tourism industry, which was hit extremely heavily. People aren't even shopping at my retail workplace because the entire country has entered what can only be described as a state of mourning.

It's impossible to describe to you just how heavily this has hit us. Nearly everybody has been directly affected in the form of smoke inhalation, there will have been thousands of heat-related and smoke-related deaths, and it will have smashed our economy, driving up the price of timber, food, services and everything else.
author: Ted Hennicke

text:

Jesus mate what is your problem spreading lies like that... if they arent shopping where you are then maybe its because you scare the hell out of them with your wacky talk... the entire country has not entered a state of mourning...Christ you are a  weirdo
author: me heretoday

text: ¬†@me heretoday¬† Well clearly I move in different circles to you. I apologise if I overstated the case. But many of my friends lost houses and livelihoods, and the climate scientists I know are all deeply depressed. And maybe the shopping centres are full, but my own workplace, which is a bicycle retailer, has been badly hit, because people are unable to ride in the smoke. I've heard similar things from a lot of other retail workers.
author: Ted Hennicke

text:
¬†@Kent Horvath¬† I'm not asking for your sympathy. I'm only asking you to understand that yes, people are in fact dying in large numbers from the indirect effects of these fires, and from a governance and economic perspective, this is a huge deal.

Of course I'm aware of death valley, and you're correct to state that the highest maximum was in 1913. But that data point needs to be qualified with the fact that the last two years have seen death valley break the global record for hottest average monthly temperature twice in a row, far surpassing the 1913 situation. Climate change is about how much heat is in the atmosphere: average temperatures over a period of time are a far better indicator of that than individual maximums.

Australia may not be hot along the coasts, but climate change has certainly made it drier along those coasts, to the point that the bushfires burned right up to the water this year, for the first time I'm aware of.

You call climate science a religion, implying it has some kind of dogma involved. That is false. If you have a problem with the conclusions that working professional scientists are reaching, a good start might be to genuinely learn about the claims these people are making, rather than making a parody out of them.
author: Ted Hennicke

text:
¬†@Kent Horvath¬† Excuse me, but I quoted a figure above that came from an academic source. Fact is, heat waves KILL people. 435 in 2009, for example.
"Across southeast Australia, the 2009 heatwave resulted in a total of nearly 500 excess deaths (Nairn & Fawcett, 2013)."[1]

If you want to know more about the process by which these deaths occur, read this article from a scientist I know at the ANU, Liz Hanna: https://theconversation.com/how-rising-temperatures-affect-our-health-123016

Smoke also kills people, such as the women who stepped off a plane and died from asphixiation at Canberra airport this year. There are people with athsma who have been unable to leave their houses for months, and plenty of deaths related to this process.

Your comments about medicine, poverty, life expectancy and so forth are completely irrelevant to the question of whether these bushfires have caused excess deaths. That's a type of logical fallacy called a "red herring". Not cool dude, not cool.

[1] 
https://www.dea.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/DEA_Heatwaves__Health_Fact_Sheet_06.pdf
author: Ted Hennicke

author: –ëƒÅŒ®‚Ä°Œ¶e √Ø≈õ ƒ¢√∞√ê

text:
¬†@Ay1¬† Do you even attempt to look up information that contradicts your worldview, or are you just happy being a total ignoramus?

You begin with a complete logical fallacy; just because I happen to know climate scientists, means nothing about what my goals are. Second, climate scientists don't have some kind of "agenda"; they're driven purely by the search for truth. If you have a problem with the conclusions they reach, join a research institute and prove them wrong with experiments and observations.

Next, Australia's per-capita emissions are almost twice that of China's. We are by FAR the worse polluter of the two countries. And that's not even accounting for historical emissions!!

And on the subject of tax dollars, you clearly have no idea that the most heavily subsidised industry on the planet is fossil fuels, to the tune of 6 trillion USD a year. This is the kind of ignorance that people like yourself, who fail to self-critique, end up displaying.

We could pay for a full transition to renewables simply by REMOVING that subsidy and giving every single tax payer a refund, globally, and letting the markets actually do their work. The markets are currently regulated heavily in favour of fossil fuels.

So before you go spouting what Daddy Murdoch and the Koch Brothers (who both have serious financial ties to fossil fuel industry) have told you through The Australian or whatever other corporate media you're reading, how about you fact-check yourself before you say something embarrasingly stupid in public?
author: Ted Hennicke

text:
¬†@Ted Hennicke¬† oh Ted. You were winning this debate until the last three paragraphs. And then you went full tribalist conspiracy theorist on us, your audience. Pity.

Anyway, greetings from a fellow Australian. 

PS. Ash Wednesday, in 1983, the fires in the Otways went all the way to the sea.
author: Brendan H

text:
¬†@Brendan H¬† Feel free to correct me. I'm only too willing to change my mind. What did I get wrong?

And sure, I concede your point about Ash Wednesday. I was more referring to the NSW south coast, because that's the area I'm more familiar with. Historically it's been too moist to burn at places like Bateman's.
author: Ted Hennicke

text:
¬†@Ted Hennicke¬† No problem. As I said, I thought you were winning. You were staying cool when others were veering to personal attacks etc. I agreed with many points you made. 

However, in the last paragraph you made a claim about the Koch brothers etc. That would only be countered by deniers claims about Soros etc. I am sure there are people with money and agendas on both sides, but either side bringing it up usually smacks of desperation because their other arguments aren't cutting through. You didn't have to go there. 

On the subsidies, there is probably more tax dollars gathered by Governments from petrol than used to subsidize fossil fuels. Probably by a long way. And those that do, do it for reasons, often to do with food security.  So good luck convincing them to stop. We have had a hard time bringing them together to an agreement on emissions reductions.
author: Brendan H

text:
¬†@Brendan H¬† No doubt there are people with money and agendas on both sides. My point was more about media trust in the face of conflicts of interest. Given that I don't get my information about climate or environment from The Guardian or SMH or whatever, but from primary sources and independent news outlets, I think it's a valid point to make. Maybe I should've made that clearer.

Re. subsidies, in 2017, fossil fuel subsidies in Australia were $29 billion. [1] In 2013-14, fuel excises brought the government a revenue of $10.8 billion [2] (and falling by the year due to increases in vehicle efficiency). So those numbers don‚Äôt quite stack up. And even if it were true that petroleum wasn‚Äôt net subsidised, it still most certainly wouldn‚Äôt be true for coal, which is a more pressing issue, and really deserves the focus at this point.

Here‚Äôs a quote along the same lines from source [1].

‚ÄúThe under-pricing of fossil fuels, particularly coal, was found to be the largest source of effective subsidy. When the wider social and environmental costs of fossil fuels were taken into account, the IMF found that price paid for coal was typically less than half of its true cost.

The report found that if fossil fuels had been priced appropriately, global carbon emissions would be reduced by 28 per cent. Significantly, effective fossil pricing would also lead to a decrease in air pollution deaths by up to 46 per cent. The elimination of fossil fuel subsidies would also increase global government revenues by 3.8 per cent of GDP.

The upward trend in global fossil fuel subsidies echoes similar analysis by the International Energy Agency that came to the same conclusion, particularly in relation to direct government support for fossil fuels.‚Äù

[1] https://reneweconomy.com.au/global-fossil-fuel-subsidies-reach-5-2-trillion-and-29-billion-in-australia-91592/ 
[2] https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/pubs/BriefingBook45p/FundingRoads

text: Here‚Äôs a tiny question. How do you grieve for a billion lost lives? I don‚Äôt mean that rhetorically. I mean it quite seriously. We must all bear witness to this terrible ecocide in Australia. Not in the way of impotent rage. Nor in the way of empty revenge. But so that our humanity is reclaimed a little bit, from the forces that have stripped it bare. Capital, money, power-seeking, arrogance, egotism, narcissism. So that we remember a great and beautiful challenge. Because if all those little ones, the ones who are wiser than us, the koalas and wombats, if they had always had inherent worth, as in the rights and resources to live, without being incinerated by walls of flame, Australians‚Äô country probably wouldn‚Äôt have burned, wither. We are in it together, my friends. From the smallest and humblest to the largest and fiercest. All those who have told you any different have always, been wrong! All those who have been trying to teach us this, Jesus, Buddha, Gandhi, MLK, have always been on the side of truth, beauty, grace, and growth. Isn‚Äôt it time we finally understood the beauty and power, and this terrible price of this truest, and yet, the oldest of lessons?   ~T.Bone~

text:
While I do not dispute global warming - I do not necessarily feel the blanket claim that Australian fires are a direct result. 


While these fires are the worst most can remember - you do not need to look too far back in history to see that in 1974 the fires burned 5 times as much (450 000 sq miles Vs 2020s current 73 000 sq miles). 


Thing is that australia has always burned. It is how many of the trees regenerate and as such they seem to burn better than most. Add to that Australia's droughts (that have been an issue in the second driest continent) since it was settled - it is a bit like complaining about blizzards in Antarctica or earthquakes in Japan.  I feel for Australia - but I also feel that people are too easily blinded by recent events without considering all the facts. There is enough misinformation out there without the media spreading rumors based on short term experiences. There is real data that supports climate change. But lets keep this news as yet another disastrous outbreak of wildfires.

text:
Iain Donald This is the most empty bunch of media-fueled clich√©s that I‚Äôve ever read. Do you think for yourself, or just rephrase verbatim from news propaganda about how we‚Äôre all doomed unless we change yesterday? 

Despair is a useless emotion, better to turn it around into something practical, like I‚Äôve done. I do not accept that we‚Äôve sealed our fate, because the Earth is over 4.5 billion years old, and never before have species been aware of gas levels in the atmosphere and tracked the data - that in itself is a massive advantage. The Earth has it‚Äôs own ways of balancing out impacts, for example where Bushfires burn and heat the upper atmospheres, very quickly this turns around to rain events. Where the Oceans absorb heat, the icecaps melt (even if just for a season). When the Earth‚Äôs orbit distances itself from the Sun (solar minimum) we see hemispheric cooling, contrary to the popular belief of ‚ÄúGlobal Warming‚Äù because it doesn‚Äôt actually warm the world over, there are inconsistencies which is why ‚Äúclimate change‚Äù was adopted. Scientists are desperate to remain relevant in the modern age of technology and global information available in seconds from a device in the palm of our hands, which is why they have to come up with terminology and ideas that we‚Äôre approaching a doomsday in order for them to secure funding that keeps them employed and food on the table for their families.

Water Vapour is the most prevalent Greenhouse Gas, yet we hear nothing of it, because it doesn‚Äôt sell and doesn‚Äôt sound as bad as Carbon Monoxide or Methane or Carbon Dioxide. 

Children do not owe their parents anything, because they were not cognisant of the decision to be bought into this world, it is the realm of the parent to plan the life for the child, and not bring them into disadvantage caused by short sightedness. Like you, I also fear for food availability in the future and have chosen not to bring extra people into this world. I‚Äôm okay with that because I feel that is responsible. I do not buy meat, partly out of principle and partly out of price, there is still plenty of dietary protein available from plant based food. Our ancestors also ate a majority plant-based diet, it‚Äôs only that excavations have located animal bones in close proximity to human remains that they‚Äôve deduced that they ate animals - but the associated plant matter that was once there has decayed a long long time ago, having left little to no trace people believed that meat protein was a staple, which it wasn‚Äôt.

text:
It's well understood that as long as there are remaining glaciers,  we are in an ice age. 

I have been saying since this spring that this would be the coldest winter for the northern hemisphere is recent memory. The science that the farmers use to predict the temperature a year in advance is the measurement of sun spots. We have been doing this since the 18th century. 

In 2019 there was more days without sun spots than days with sun spots.

If you do a cursory google search for "solar minimum", you will be bombarded with "the solar minimum myth is back, pee your pants because the end of the world is still here" results.

I have given you the clues, now use logic and judgement to decide for yourself after a bit of research. Ask yourself who do you believe, climate bloggers and little highschool dropouts girls named greta, or scientists with super telescopes and sun-orbitting sattelites.

text: ¬†@April A¬† In terms of duration, it is the worst. In terms of hectares burned, we don't know because we didn't measure that very well back in 1939 when black Friday occurred. In terms of life lost, black Saturday (2007) and Ash Wednesday (1983) both lost far more, and the current event doesn't even get in the top five since 1939. author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@Brendan H¬† Now consider the resources being put into fighting these fires compared to past ones & the extent of these ones becomes obvious doesn't it! How many 737 planes filled with water & fire retardant were employed in 1939, 1983 or even 2007?
& we really don't even have to measure to know that fires burning for the time these ones have been burning for will have burnt far more bush than ones burning for only a short period! Not rocket science! We also know people had at least some idea of areas burnt back then didn't they, additionally we can measure today based on tree growth, so we are more than capable of confirming their measurements, which to date show those fires to be 10 times smaller than this year's fires don't they! To try to claim they couldn't measure is just another cop out! You know full well this year's fires are much bigger! Additionally we know that the 1939 fires were put out after just over a month of burning for the longest burners, with a day of RAIN! We have had a week or torrential rain & flooding in the bushfire areas this year but the fires have persisted despite that, which makes it abundantly clear that these fires are far more intense doesn't i! We also know that the majority of the 1939 fires were started deliberately by people thinking they could protect their properties & selves by backburning. How many amateur people today look at the fires they are seeing & think "oh I think I can start a fire & maintain full control over it & it will be a good idea"? The fact that people aren't dreaming of doing that tells you that they know the fires today are far worse than the 1939 ones!


How much evidence do you want that this year's fires are worse? Developing better management strategies to save lives & homes doesn't mean the fire isn't as severe!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@Lilac Lizard¬† Thanks Lilac Lizard. The point of my post was not to necessarily dispute that this is the worst fire season we've had, but to show that there are many and complex ways to view a seemingly simple idea of "worst" fires. Note also that on two of the four measures that I used, the current fires are the worst. 

In comparison to previous years, this is less intense than either Ash Wednesday (1983) and Black Saturday (2007) which left a (far larger) toll in human lives and homes (nearly as great as the current fires), in a much shorter time period. I believe that this is due to better management of the fires (especially prioritizing people over property, as well as better resources to draw from,  as you pointed out), better education and communication of the affected communities, and a more fortunate location of the fires. But the very length of the fire season is very draining. 

On your point about the ability to back measure where forests have burned, I stand corrected if I left the impression that attempts to compare hadn't been done. Although my point about it being difficult to measure and to make accurate comparisons with today's fires still stands. As an example, one scientific paper (MacFarlane, Australian Forestry, 1988) estimated that 79% of Victoria's mountain ash forests burned during the 1939 fires. (For comparison, Victoria contains about half as much forest as NSW, where the bulk of this current fires have been, and most of it is in the central highlands Northeast of Melbourne). If this is true, the current fires may well have some way to go to catch up, in terms of area burned. My point isn't to say that this publication is the truth, but to show that making seemingly simple comparisons is fraught with uncertainty. So the scientifically judicious viewpoint is "we don't really know", which is what I stated. With the rise of aerial photography and satellite imaging, it is much easier to make such measurements today, and errors are much tighter. But this wasn't the case in 1939.
author: Brendan H

text:
‚Äã¬†@Bonnie Nutter¬† I live here, I worked at Lindfield during the 1994 fires, at a location that was gutted by the fires, but we had 3 days notice it was coming & we needed to evacuate. This season I watched the Turramurra blaze (an arson one) from my home, I'm too far away to have seen the actual flames & I didn't even see the 737 fly over & drop it's fire extinguishing load, probably due to the smoke, watching that smoke was scary! The speed the sky went from nothing to orange to black was freaky! Nothing like those in Victoria are describing, but watching it over a half hour period, after having been in the ones in the nearby suburb years earlier, it is obvious the difference between now & then!


In terms of arson, there is less arson in NSW this year than most! People are too scared to be lighting fires. Just because the coal industry supporters are promoting stories about 200 people who don't speak English & don't live anywhere near any bush lighting BBQ's on their inner city apartment balconies & their neighbours are calling the police to report them & the police are attending & giving them official cautions for lighting fires, doesn't mean there's suddenly an influx of arson! Traditionally most bushfires in Australia have been the result of arson, now it's mostly lightning, especially for the large ones. Here's a full story on the largest Australian bushfire ever & how lightning started it https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/the-monster-a-short-history-of-australia-s-biggest-forest-fire-20191218-p53l4y.html & here's the weather systems being caused by these mega-fires & how they light more fires https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-01-01/why-bushfires-that-spin-are-incredibly-dangerous/11834006
Apparently though, you're not interested in any of that, because I'm just an Australian, not an Australian business person & you're only interested in businesspeople's views for some reason, maybe because they tend to lean right & think global warming is a hoax? (at least they say that, they all know it's not, they just say the political lines of their party). Fyi, there are MUCH easier ways to identify Aussies talking about the fires, simple terminology & spelling will give away who's Aussie & who's not with ease, but I really don't think you want to hear from Aussies, only a very select sub-group of Aussies that you have found to be spouting your pre-decided views. If you listen to general Aussies, you will find your claims are NOT supported at all!
& starting a gofundme page for ONE person right now just shows how out of touch & disconnected from what's going on these people you are associating with are! It's not like there's 1 single mother out there that's lost everything you know! Centrelink are on the ground, with their mobile services & online support to assist those sorts of people & the red cross is there too, linking them to the various services & people donating clothing & other needs & those professional services are also providing physiological support & long term support for rebuilding, to try to separate individuals from proper long term support instead of just donating to established services imo just shows those people to be selfish & wanting to make it about them, instead of about the people they're claiming they want to help. I'd put it to you that it is even possible that those people who are talking about Aussies being scum (lighting fires) may themselves be the scum of the earth & may not even be passing those donations on, but rather pocketing the money. Like it or not, there are bad eggs out there & you certainly sound like you have found some!


In Sydney at least, you cannot have a conversation with anyone without the topic turning to how bad the fires are this year & how we've never seen anything like it before (mostly referring to the air quality, which is an inescapable reality of daily life right now! Better since the recent rain, but even tonight, when I went outside after dark to water my garden, at first I thought it was raining, but the ground was dry, I then realised what I was watching in the torchlight raining down on me was ash! That's even when the air doesn't smell of smoke & when there's no obvious reduced visibility! And that's from LIGHTING fires NOT arson ones!)


https://www.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/fires-near-me If it's in a metropolitan area, it's arson (or idiot), if it's in a non-metro area, it's lightning, if it's near another fire it's ember or firestorm lit. This year, as you can see, next to none are metro!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
‚Äã¬†@Brendan H¬† imo these fires are by far the worst fires we have seen, but also by far the best managed, therefore less lives and homes lost as a result of good management. I think we both agree on that?


"So the scientifically judicious viewpoint is "we don't really know"" rubbish! The numbers for this fire season are 10 times more bush burnt than in 1939, we know for a fact the numbers from 1939 were NOT recorded as over 10 times less area burnt than was in fact burnt!


" 79% of Victoria's mountain ash forests burned during the 1939 fires. (For comparison, Victoria contains about half as much forest as NSW" That's just straight out deception on your part isn't it! You're comparing 1 mountain tree species with entire forests of another state! So I googled mountain ash trees to see how common they are & found, surprise surprise, they are limited to mountain areas - which is not a lot of Victoria is it! They are also a rainforest tree & only grow in areas with seriously high rainfall, which again tells you they are not found in much of Victoria! Additionally, wiki says "Most of the E. regnans forest across Gippsland was cleared for farmland between 1860 and 1880, and in the Otway Ranges between 1880 and 1900" so yeh, you've provided absolutely nothing to indicate in any way that the stats from each even, this one showing 10 times the area of 1939 being burnt were off at all, let alone off tenfold! In fact, when we look at other stats from the past, we see that there is usually an over estimation not an under estimation, so if the 1939 numbers are off, it is far more likely to be similar to temperature reading of the past & that in the future it is found that they were seriously exaggerated NOT downplayed! There is no question these fires have burnt FAR more area than the 1939 ones - unless the flat earth someone changes amounts burnt over time, that's the only way I can see the numbers could be as far off as you are claiming

text:
Bull Shit!  
It's the fuel load - greens style policies have prevented property owners from burning off to reduce undergrowth/fuel load in the bush on their properties as they used to do which means the fires can burn slower and cooler and gives the fire fighters time to put it out or build fire breaks to divert it from homes and populated areas.
Our fire season is normal.
Fire is even beneficial and necessary for our Australian bush, as some trees require it to propagate.
The normal cyclical pattern of climate in Australia is drought, flood, drought, flood, etc - nothing new here.

text: Let's dispel once and for all the delusion that all of the fires were caused by arsonists. 25 arsonists have been arrested, and they are responsible for the much smaller-scale fires. Climate change is real, people. No-one is saying that "climate change started the fires". What's happening is that climate change is creating and exacerbating conditions necessary for wildfires to start (e.g. much drier conditions, warmer surface temperatures...). One of the main reasons for which the fires spread so rapidly and so intensely is because of conditions generated by climate change.

text:
¬†@Gandalfdenvite¬† Lol.

There is no "right-wing" mainstream media.

Sigh.

The purpose of Fox, and other sources you probably consider "fascist" or "right-wing" is to form one side of the Overton Window.

The same goes for "right-wing" or "conservative" political parties.

They are teammates of the "left-wing" media/parties/e-celebs etc.

They are all globalists. 
They are all progressives. 
They are all radical Leftists.
They all want redistribution of wealth. 
They all want to reduce the birth rate of Western peoples even further below replacement levels. 

A good personal example is Jordan Peterson.

He is promoted as "right-wing" in the media, or at least as holding an extreme opposing position to progressivism.

In reality he is a globalist progressive whose expertise in psychology got him hired to rewrite globslist publications, in order to make them appear less obviously Communist. 

If the extreme limit towards the right is presented as Fox news, and their statements and coverage is taken as "the opposition", then naturally any result of debate between the two 'sides' can only fall somewhere between the two Poles. 

The goal is to constantly shift the Overton Window farther and farther left. 

"Center" is now extreme left. 
"far right" is now far-left. 
Any belief or idea beyond this "far-right" is impossible for the public to imagine. 

Think of it like this:

Two pans of water, both lukewarm, one being chilled with ice, the other kept at a constant temperature. 

You place your hand in lukewarm water (we will call this the center). It feels comfortable, not too hot, not too cold. 

Now you start to chill with ice. 
It gets colder and colder as the minutes tick by, eventually it is just  a few degrees above freezing but it really feels fine! 

Now, you take that hand and plunge it into the other pan, the one that still contains lukewarm water. 

OUCH! It BURNS!

What happened? The temp in the first pan changed so slowly that your mind and body barely perceived the shift. Eventually you experience it to be the new normal. By comparison, lukewarm (the center) now feels VERY HOT. 
If cold is left and hot is right, far-left is now the new center. You can even put your hand in FREEZING water below zero celsius (salt added) and it feels quite tolerable... you could even get used to it as frostbite starts to kill your fingers. 

On the other side, if you now try to put your hand into HOT water, which previously would have felt like a nice comfy, freshly poured bath, it hurts, you feel a BURNING PAIN and instinctively flinch, jerking your hand out of the water which, despite being only bath temp, now feels BOILING. 

"I definitely don't want to touch that you think to yourself. " 

This is what has happened in politics and society due to a constant flow of increasingly far-left propaganda, television series, movies, magazines, school and university curricula, laws and govt policies. 

All parties are "progressive." 
All media is "progressive." 
All curricula are "progressive."

The presence of "right wing" or "fascist" media and politicians are merely a distortion of your perception of "center." 

This incremental shifting to create a new "normal" is sometimes called Hegelian Dialectic.

Did you ever ask yourself what is the destination of all this "progress"? 

Here is a clue, Read Orwell "1984" and Huxley "Brave New World."

Huxley was an insider, his brother was directly involved in the long term plans we are now seeing come to fruition.

text: Our bush in Australia needs fire... as some trees require fire to propagate.  Bush management is the ticket (burning off in winter months so there is less fuel load and clearing decent fire breaks), so we can do regular slow, cool burns to help the bush, protect the animals and people living among it.
